block.p: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast.
Opera

''MARRIAGE OF FIGARO.'' The homespun but attractive qualities of the Amato Opera's productions and the intimacy of its shoe-box theater offer a useful change of perspective for operagoers used to the big houses uptown. The casts here vary: at the very least, the singers are eager and enthusiastic; sometimes the singing shows great promise. And Anthony Amato, the company's founder, conducts the performances with an evident love of the music. The closing production of the company's season is Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro,'' performed in English. Tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30, Sunday at 2:30 p.m., Amato Opera Theater, 319 Bowery, at Second Street, East Village; (212) 228-8200. Tickets: $25; $20 for the elderly and children (Allan Kozinn).

Classical Music

AMERICAN BOYCHOIR. This chorus did excellent work in Bach's St. John Passion in April with Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic. Here, conducted by its music director, James Litton, and with the New York Collegium playing period instruments, it performs works by Franz Joseph Haydn's younger brother, Michael, a fascinating composer in his own right. The pieces, Missa ''St. Leopoldi'' and ''Vesperae pro festo sanctissimae innocentium,'' will later be recorded by Linn Records for release in the fall. Sunday at 7 p.m., Richardson Auditorium, Princeton University, Princeton, N.J., (609) 258-5000. Tickets: $15 to $25; $10 for students (James R. Oestreich).

BACHANALIA CHAMBER ORCHESTRA. The group concludes its season, devoted mostly to 20th-century music, with a wide-ranging program. Nina Beilina, a violinist and the artistic director, is the soloist in two preludes and fugues from Bach's ''Well-Tempered Clavier,'' arranged for string orchestra by Philip Lasser. Villa-Lobos's ''Bachiana Brasileira'' No. 9 is presented alongside real Bach, an aria from the ''St. Matthew Passion.'' The orchestra also plays Schoenberg's ''Verklarte Nacht'' and, in its premiere, Jacob Jakoulov's ''Romance.'' Tonight at 8, St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, (203) 938-2924. Tickets: $20; $10 for students and the elderly (Oestreich).

GARLAND FOR LINDA. After Linda McCartney died of breast cancer in 1998, Sir Paul McCartney commissioned a group of composers to write a series of choral works that would commemorate his wife and help raise money for the Garland Appeal, which supports breast cancer research and other causes. Among those who responded were Sir John Tavener, Roxana Panufnik, Judith Bingham, John Rutter, David Matthews, Michael Berkeley, Giles Swayne and Sir Richard Rodney Bennett. Sir Paul, who has been writing classical music lately, also supplied a work for the collection, which is called ''A Garland for Linda.'' EMI recently released a recording of the set, which is to be performed in concert (along with choral arrangements of a few Beatles songs) tomorrow at 7:45 p.m. at Riverside Church, Riverside Drive at 122nd Street, Morningside Heights; (212) 307-4100 or (800) 755-4000. Tickets: $30 to $250 (Kozinn).

GOLDEN FLEECE. The company presents new music-theater pieces. ''Owl in Love,'' by the Philharmonic bassist and humorist Jon Deak, is based on a Haitian folk tale. ''Happy Valentine'' is a love triangle, with lyrics by William Cotter and music by Lou Rodgers. Scenes from Matthew Harris's ''Tess,'' after the Thomas Hardy novel, complete the program. Today, tomorrow and Monday at 8 p.m., Sunday at 3 and 8 p.m.; Theater 22, 54 West 22nd Street, Chelsea; (212) 691-6105. Tickets: $15, students and seniors $12 (Paul Griffiths).

HUDSON VALLEY CHAMBER MUSIC CIRCLE. Joseph Kalichstein, Jaime Laredo and Sharon Robinson, pianist, violinist and cellist, are familiar to New Yorkers from their fine series of concerts each season at the 92nd Street Y. Here they take the show up the river. The program sets classics -- Beethoven's B flat Trio (Op. 11) and Brahms's wonderfully expansive B major Trio (Op. 8) -- against Richard Danielpour's ''Child's Reliquary,'' which these players recently gave its premiere. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Olin Hall, Bard College, Route 9G, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y.; (914) 338-1172. Tickets: $20; $15 for the elderly; $5 for students (Oestreich).

MANHATTAN CHAMBER CHOIR AND ORCHESTRA OF SACRED MUSIC. The conductor, choir director, organist and pianist Robert Prior founded the Manhattan Chamber Choir and Orchestra of Sacred Music last year to perform music from various eras of Roman Catholic tradition. Two works on its program tonight, the final concert of the ensemble's season, can be said to emanate from that tradition: Liszt's Missa Choralis for chorus and orchestra, and Britten's ''Rejoice in the Lamb,'' a cantata for chorus and organ. But claiming the work that concludes the program, Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 9 in E flat, as part of the Catholic tradition is a stretch. Still, it's a great piece and fits nicely into the program for this free concert. Mr. Prior, who will conduct, is also the pianist for the concerto. Church of the Holy Innocents, 128 West 37th Street, Manhattan. Tonight at 7:30. Admission is free. Information: (718) -224-5721 (Anthony Tommasini).

MUSIC BEFORE 1800. This group belies its title by going to Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon and presenting sacred music written after 1977. The pieces, all American, are by Catherine Aks, Harvey Burgett, Jackson Hill, David MacBride, Louise Talma and Maurice Wright. Louise Basbas is the group's music director. At Christ Church and Holy Family, 326 Clinton Street, Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets, $15; $10 for students and the elderly; (212) 666-9266. (Bernard Holland).

NEW CHAMBER MUSIC. The musicians are Robert Frankenberry (piano), Roger Zahab (violin) and David Russell (cello). Mr. Zahab is also one of the composers, in company with Elliott Carter (''Figment'' for solo cello), Judith Weir (Piano Trio), Tamar Diesendruck, Harold Meltzer, C. Bryan Rulon and Dennis Riley. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., St. Peter's Episcopal Church, 346 West 20th Street, Chelsea; (212) 741-0011. Tickets: $10; students and the elderly, $8 (Griffiths).

NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. Like many other German conductors, Kurt Masur spent formative years of his youth without the music of Mahler, which was banned under the Nazis' anti-Semitic policies. But he has warmed to a few of the symphonies. He conducted the Philharmonic in the First recently at Carnegie Hall, and here, to end the orchestra's season, he leads the valedictory Ninth, which he and the Philharmonic recorded six years ago for Teldec. With an end to Mr. Masur's eventful tenure as music director now in sight, though still two seasons away, performances of monumental works like this take on added significance. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center; (212) 875-5030 or (212) 721-6500. Tickets: $18 to $77; the performances are sold out, but returns may be available (Oestreich).

BERNADETTE SPEACH AND THULANI DAVIS. The pianist and composer Bernadette Speach and the poet Thulani Davis have been collaborating on new works in recent years. They are presenting some of their most recent pieces, including ''Passages and Outtakes'' and ''Woman Without Adornment,'' with Ms. Davis reciting the texts, Ms. Speach at the piano, Alva Rogers as vocalist and Jeffrey Schanzer on guitar. Tomorrow at 8 p.m. Lafayette Avenue Presbyterian Church, Lafayette Avenue and South Oxford Street, Fort Greene, Brooklyn; (718) 972-3085. Tickets: $7. (Kozinn)

WILD GINGER PHILHARMONIC. This colorfully named ensemble of young, energetic players has developed an enthusiastic following since it was founded by David Goodman in 1995. The Brahms Third Symphony is the centerpiece of its program this time. Included as well are Wagner's ''Tannhauser'' Overture and Humperdinck's Overture to ''Hansel and Gretel.'' Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, Good Shepherd-Faith Presbyterian Church, 152 West 66th Street, Manhattan; (212) 879-1363. Tickets: suggested donation is $20, $10 for students and the elderly (Kozinn).
Dance

AMERICAN BALLET THEATER. Like the film fare at Saturday children's matinees -- do they still exist? -- ''Le Corsaire'' teems with swashbuckling pirates, pretty slave women and skulking villains. Buried in its endearingly old-fashioned melodrama are gems of classical ballet and opportunities for fireworks, like the ''Corsaire'' pas de deux. Today at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20 to $75. Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; (212) 362-6000 (Jennifer Dunning).

H. T. CHEN AND DANCERS. The interweaving of generations and cultures in Asian-American families is celebrated in ''Bian Dan.'' The choreography makes expressive use of bamboo shoulder poles used throughout Asia to carry loads, and in various scenes they come to symbolize burdens, oracle sticks and building materials. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3:30 and 8 p.m., La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village; (212) 475-7710. Tickets: $20 tonight and tomorrow; $15 Sunday (Jack Anderson).

CHOREOGRAPHERS GROUP. Modern dance from Boston by Lillian Carter, Perla Joy Furr and Carol Somers, who was named one of the top 10 best in dance in 1999 by The Boston Globe. Tonight through Sunday night at 8:30. Tickets: $12. Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village; (212) 674-8194 Also at Danspace this weekend will be dance by Joyce S. Lim and Nami Yamamoto exploring the subtleties of intertwined Asian cultures as part of the theater's free informal Draftwork series, an informal showcase for works in progress. Tomorrow at 3 p.m.; reservations necessary (Dunning).

DANCE AFRICA 2000. The always vibrant, spirited Dance Africa festival returns with African and African-American dance by Genies Noirs from Benin, Djoule African from West Africa and America's own Rennie Harris Puremovement and the BAM/Restoration Dance Africa Ensemble. Today at 7:30 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $15 to $38; half-price for children 16 and under. Howard Gilman Opera House, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene; (718) 636-4100. The festival also includes an outdoor bazaar, feature films and a cabaret (Dunning).

DANCES PATRELLE. Francis Patrelle, a choreographer who believes in the enduring classical ballet canon, will present his new ''Notturno for Strings and Harp,'' set to music by Irving Fine, and recent pieces set to music by Schubert, Bruch and Stephen Foster. Youngsters will be welcomed onto the stage to dance with the performers at the end of the matinee on Sunday, a special program for children. Today at 7:30 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 7:30 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $25; $20 for adults and $10 for children under 10 at the Sunday matinee. Theater of the Riverside Church, 91 Claremont Avenue, Morningside Heights; (212) 870-6784 (Dunning).

DUENDE FLAMENCO. Ignore it at your peril. Presented by the World Music Institute, two troupes will present flamenco. Performing tonight is the Manuel Soler Company, whose dancers include Mr. Soler, a percussionist and flamenco dancer; Juana Amaya; Fernando Romero; and Israel Galvan, known as the ''Nijinsky of Flamenco.'' Tomorrow night brings the Carmen Cortes Company, including Ms. Cortes and Rafael del Carmen, in a New York debut. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8. Tickets: $35 for each program. Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street; (212) 864-5400. (Dunning).

FRIDAYS AT NOON.This informal free series of works in progress and dance by new choreographers, followed by discussion with the participants, presents Naomi Pressman, Carolyn Dorfman and Nathaniel Lee. Today at noon. Buttenweiser Hall, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue; (212) 996-1100 (Dunning)

ANDREA HAENGGI. The Swiss choreographer Andrea Haenggi will present ''Cradle Rocking in Quicksand,'' a dance for six women that is rooted in the rocking motion of the cradle. Tonight through Sunday night at 8. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and artists. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street; (212) 334-7479 (Dunning).

BRYAN HAYES AND CAROLYN LORD. Two choreographers known for their meditative, intelligent approach to dance, Bryan Hayes and Carolyn Lord, will present new works set to music by composers including Bartok, Tchaikovsky, Bach, Xenakis and Morton Feldman. Mr. Hayes will also present a video, set to live music, that explores the body in landscapes and the landscape of the body. Tomorrow through Tuesday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12; $10 for students and the elderly; TDF vouchers accepted. Music Under Construction, 10 East 18th Street, Manhattan; (212) 924-7882 (Dunning).

JOHN JASPERSE COMPANY. A double bill pairs ''Ft. Blossom,'' a new work about the nature of change, with ''Excessories,'' a choreographic commentary on styles of dressing and concepts of the beautiful and the ugly. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8, the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea; (212) 255-5793. Tickets: $15 (Anderson).

ANGELA JONES. Angela Jones is known for her intense physical energy and stage presence. Her company includes the tap dancer Barbara Duffy, the ballerina Eva Evdokimova and the aerialist Chelsea Bacon. Sounds promisingly odd. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $15; T.D.F. vouchers accepted. Clark Studio Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center; (718) 630-5664 (Dunning).

JENNIFER MULLER/THE WORKS. An exuberant modern-dance company celebrates its 25th anniversary with programs crammed with premieres on many themes and in many styles. ''Beethoven -- Not Four Naught'' resembles a dialogue between dancers and a Beethoven quartet; ''Spores, Solitude and Summer Humming'' is inspired by patterns of spore reproduction; ''aSOlo'' is a stream-of-consciousness blending of movements and words. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: $32 (Anderson).

NEW FACES NEW VOICES NEW VISIONS. This series, an invaluable incubator of talent, presents a look at the old and the new. Two alumni, Ronald K. Brown and Marlies Yearby, will present premieres tomorrow that are set to music by the Staple Singers, Aretha Franklin, Wunmi Olaiya and Cooper Moore. The fledgling dancemakers that Mr. Brown and Ms. Yearby once were will move in with new dances on Sunday. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 5 p.m. Tickets: $18 (tomorrow); $12 (Sunday); $10 tickets for students available one hour before the performances. Aaron Davis Hall, City College, West 134th Street and Convent Avenue, Hamilton Heights; (212) 650-7289 (Dunning).

NEW YORK CITY BALLET. For all his reputation as the master of non-narrative ballet, George Balanchine knew how to tell a good story in dance. He and Alexandra Danilova came up with a confectionary delight in their staging of ''Coppelia,'' a lighthearted romp with dark undertones featuring a village lass, her homespun fiance and a mad old toymaker. In addition to ''Coppelia'' (tomorrow night and Sunday afternoon), City Ballet will dance a mixed bill that includes a new ballet by Kevin O'Day (tonight) and an all-Balanchine program (tomorrow afternoon). Today at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 3 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $72; $10 for student rush tickets. New York State Theater, Lincoln Center; (212) 870-5570 (Dunning).

TANGO & TANGO. Need one say more? Today at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 3 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at 4 p.m. Through June 18. Tickets: $20; $18 for students, children and the elderly. Thalia Spanish Theater, 41-17 Greenpoint Avenue, Sunnyside, Queens; (718) 729-3880 (Dunning).

YOSHIKO TAKESHIGE. A performer and folk dance scholar who trained in Japan, Taiwan and China, Yoshiko Takeshige will present ''Wandering'' (''Ruro''), a full-evening piece in an idiom Ms. Takeshige considers to be modern Noh dance. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. Remaining tickets: $15, $35 and $50. Alice Tully Hall, Lincoln Center; (212) 721-6500 (Dunning).

''THEME AND VARIATIONS.'' Images from ballet, lyrical and full of passion, will be on view in an exhibit by the dance photographer known as Costas. The exhibit also includes dance sculptures by Andrew De Vries, paintings by Douglas Hofmann and aquatints by Roy Fairchild-Woodard. Today and tomorrow (and Monday through Saturday through July 1) from 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Free. The Gallery at Lincoln Center, concourse level just beneath the Metropolitan Opera House; (212) 580-4673 (Dunning).

DURA MATER'S ''I, RASPUTIN.'' Kriota Willberg draws from Russian folk dance, ballroom and etiquette manuals, stage combat, silent movies and political cartoons and lithographs from the time of the ''mad monk'' Rasputin. Today through Sunday (and Thursday through June 11) at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $15. Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street, East Village; (212) 477-5288 (Dunning).

WOMEN'S COALITION: ''PORTRAITS OF OUR SOUL: THE SECOND LEVEL OF MEANING.'' Dances, influenced by yoga and meditation, by Angela Caponigro, Sue Hogan, Dalienne Majors and Nilaya. Today at 9 p.m.; tomorrow and Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12. Merce Cunningham Studio, 55 Bethune Street, West Village; (718) 399-7689 (Dunning).

YOUNG DANCERS: LA GUARDIA HIGH SCHOOL. Graduating students from the school depicted in ''Fame'' -- whose alumni include Eliot Feld, Arthur Mitchell and Edward Villella -- will perform in works by Penny Frank, Gabriela Granados, Roger C. Jeffrey, Elisa King and James Sutton and in ''Raymonda Variations,'' staged by Brunilda Ruiz and Paul Sutherland. Tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 2 and 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $6 (no reservations). La Guardia Concert Hall, 100 Amsterdam Avenue, at 64th Street, Manhattan; (212) 496-0700, ext. 2837 (Dunning).

YOUNG DANCERS: SCHOOL OF AMERICAN BALLET. Whether this year's graduates find their way into the New York City Ballet or companies elsewhere in the nation, they dance with a gleaming pedigree. The ballets are ''Danses Concertantes'' and ''Stars and Stripes,'' both by Balanchine and staged by Susan Pilarre and Suki Schorer, respectively, and Bournonville's ''Konservatoriet,'' staged by Nikolaj Hubbe. Tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Monday at 7 p.m. Tickets: $25 (tomorrow); $45 (Monday). Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center; (212) 769-6600 (Dunning).
